# Introduction

Bootstrap and package your project with Angular 7 and Electron (Typescript + SASS + Hot Reload) for creating Desktop applications.

Currently runs with:

- Angular v7.2.7
- Electron v5.0.2
- Electron Builder v20.28.1
- node v10.16.0

With this sample, you can :

- Run your app in a local development environment with Electron & Hot reload
- Run your app in a production environment
- Package your app into an executable file for Linux, Windows & Mac

1Introduction

1.1Document Objectives & Scope

This document describes application architecture and design for Raphael device. It provides high-level overview of architectural representation and various aspects of the application that are to be considered during system architecture phase.

The intent of this document is to address the following:

Provide Logical architecture for USB application
Define high level design for cross cutting concerns for USB application
Provide modularized framework development approach
Elaborate the recommended pattern/techniques specific to application development
Present best practices, standards and guidelines that are to be used in USB application
Capture recommended tools and packages that are widely used in USB application development
The document briefly elaborates the packaging and deployment techniques for Development, Staging and Production
1.2Intended Audience
The target audience of this document includes:

The system design team
The development teams
Other stakeholders who would like to get a technical overview and familiarization of USB application
2SOFTWARE REQUIREMENTS SPECIFICATION
Refer Requirement document

3ARCHITECTURE

1.3Architecture Overview

     ![](data:image/*;base64,)

Figure 1 – Raphael USB Application Architecture Overview

1.4Logical Architecture

Figure 2 – Raphael USB Application Logical Architecture

Raphael USB application is designed to support cross platform desktop application. Electron framework is chosen to support the cross-platform application development using web technologies. Electron bundles chromium and native NodeJS modules while creating OS specific packages. It comes with electron-builder that supports converting the electron API to native API to support the OS specific interfaces.

Angular framework is used to implement user interface components and services. Angular is a web application development framework that aids in creating single page application.

Nodejs modules are used to interact with device interfacing system and OS file system. Node-HID module is identified to interface with the device for most of the capabilities required by USB application. For those capabilities that are not supported by the Node-HID module, like device connection detection, suitable modules will be identified, or custom node module will be developed.

Electron hosts the Angular application using chromium module, electron uses inter process communication (IPC) services to exchange the communication between Angular elements and Node modules.

Application framework is developed to support the cross-cutting functionalities like logger, error handler, authentication, etc., Reusable UI elements, consists of both native elements as well as the Angular elements are also part of the application framework. These elements are to be used as per the need of the requirements in USB Application.

Each of the application module is logically separated out; each of them implements specific presentation components, services, node controllers and electron IPC services.

1.5Communication Model

The above figure depicts the high-level communication between Raphael device and the application platform. In this flow, it's designed to use a common interface (Adaptor) to communicate with Raphael device from USB App and Web app.

As shown in the image there will be two channel one for USB app which will be implemented with Electron and node and another channel which uses web socket and D-Bus.

With this Adaptor interface the app will use maximum of two channel one for send and one for receive with Electron.

Web Sockets

Web sockets are defined as a two-way communication between the server and the clients, which mean both parties communicate and exchange data at the same item. This feature is called full duplex.

Web Sockets – Events

There are four main Web Sockets API events, viz.,

Open -For connection establishment between client & server
Message - Data transfer from Server
Close - To close connection
Error - Provides error detail
Web Sockets – Actions

send () - Sending messages (files, binary data, ext.,)
close () - Terminates the connection
Low Level Communication Module

Reports

The data exchange between USB App and Raphael device is done through Reports.

Reports are the actual data blobs that are exchanged between a Raphael device and USB App. The Report Descriptor describes the format and meaning of each data blob that it supports.

There are three report types: Input Reports, Output Reports, and Feature Reports.

Input Report

Items that are ONLY transmitted from Raphael device to USB App.

Output Report

Items that are ONLY transmitted from USB App to Raphael device.

Feature Report

Unlike Input or Output data items, which can only be read by USB App or only be written by the USB App, any Feature data item can either be written by the USB App or read back by the USB App. This means that any data item that we want to be able to set from the USB App, and then be able to read back later, should be a Feature item.

1. 1.5.1USB App to DEVICE AND vice versa (feature report)
   This communication will be initiated from USB app and interact with Device and get response back from the device about the status. The communication can be reversed in similar way.

1) 1.5.2Device to USB app (input report)
   This kind of communication will happen, when the USB App have to be updated based on Raphael device events.

For example, user may press mute button of Raphael device.

1. 1.5.3USB app to device (output report)
   This kind of communication will happen, from USB App to Raphael device.

For example, user may want to save preset data to Raphael device from USB App.

1. 1.5.4Node-HID Communication Model
1. 1.5.4.1Device Detection
   Device detection can be done using the ' node-usb-detection' package. Using HID.HID() or new HID.HID() from node-hid package will cause time consumption and slow down the read/write operation when doing in parallel with device.

Ref: https://github.com/MadLittleMods/node-usb-detection

var usbDetect = require('usb-detection');

usbDetect.find(vid, pid, callback)

Ref: https://www.npmjs.com/package/node-hid

Opening (Connecting) with Device

var device =** new** HID.HID(path);

The path value can be retrieved using, HID.devices() call.

(Or)

var device =** new** HID.HID(vid,pid);

vid – vendorId

pid – productId

1.

1. 1.5.4.2Reading from a device
   For input reports,

device.on("data", function(data) { call back function});

1.

1. 1.5.4.3Writing to a device
   To send output reports,

device.write() – return number of bytes written

To Send Feature Reports

device.sendFeatureReport() - return number of bytes written

To get Feature Reports

var buf = device.getFeatureReport(reportId, reportLength)

device.close() will release all event handlers.

Error Listener

device.on("error", function(err) { call back function });

Electron IPC – Inter Process Communication (Asynchronous)

There are two modules involved in IPC, viz...,

electron.ipcMain – handling communication in the main process

election.ipcRenderer – handling communication in renderer process

From Renderer to Main process and vice versa

In Renderer

ipcRenderer.send('channel', 'args from renderer')

In Main

ipcMain.on('channel', e, args) =&gt; {

callback function

})

The 'channel' (string value) here used to identify and organize IPC traffic. This identifier used by renderer to communicate with main process.

e - Event object from renderer.

args – arguments from renderer.

ipcMain.once – this method will terminate of listening after first listen.

From within Main listener to Renderer

In Main

ipcMain.on('channel', e, args) =&gt; {

callback function

e.sender.send('channel', 'return response object')

})

In Renderer

ipcRenderer.on('channel', (e, args) =&gt; {

          callback function

})

As highlighted, the identifier needs to match for the communication between main and renderer.

From Main to Renderer Directly

mainwindow.webContents.on('did-finish-load', e =&gt; {

          mainwindow.webContents.send(&#39;from-main&#39;, &#39;object to renderer&#39;)

})

mainwindow – Browser window object i.e., mainwindow = new BrowserWindow(……..)

Here we are using web content instance (mainwindow.webContents) directly send messages to the renderer after it loaded. We are not using main process listener block.

In Renderer

ipcRenderer.on('from-main, (e, args) =&gt; {

          callback function

}

IPC – Inter Process Communication (Synchronous)

From Renderer to Main

In Renderer

let fromMain = ipcRenderer.sendSync('syncmsg', 'object to main process')

In Main

ipcMain.on('syncmsg', (e, args) =&gt; {

          e.returnValue = &#39;return object to renderer&#39;

})

In this communication, the renderer will wait for the main process response (synchronous) after it sends message to main. It will be in blocked state until it receives response from main process.

1.6Sequence of events

4APPLICATION FRAMEWORK

1.7Logging

'Electron-Log' logging module used in desktop application to trace the application flow and to know the errors occur in the application.

To make use of 'electron-log' module in node.js and electron folder, developed a common service called 'loggerService.ts' file under shared/logger folder.

Import the above loggerService file in particular node and electron application file, use the below Syntax to make use of the logLevels.

loggerService.trace(data);

loggerService.error(data);

loggerService.info(data);

loggerService.warn(data);

loggerService.debug(data);

1. 1.7.1Log levels
   Following are the log levels:

error, warn, info, verbose, debug

Below are the syntaxes of each method used and the syntax:

import { Logger } from '@core/logger/Logger';

this.logger.info('display application related information');-This method is used to display information logs related to application.

this.logger.debug('display application related debug logs');- This method is used to display debug logs related to application.

this.logger.error('display application related error logs ');- This method is used to display the error logs occur in the application.

this.logger.verbose('display application related information');- This method is used to display the trace logs in the application.

this.logger.warn('display application related information');

1. 1.7.2Log-Level Hierarchy
   Error=5, warn=4, info=3, Verbose=2, debug=1

'silly' log level is not used, because it is default log level.
0 is the default level, and Error is the highest level, above is the log- heirarchy shown.
Configure the logLevel as 'debug'(logLevel: 'debug'),it will show that level and higher level of logs, it will not display the low level of logs(in this case it will not display silly logs).
Configure logLevel as 'info' (logLevel: 'info') it will display info, warn and error logs and it will not show or print the low-level logs for verbose, debug, silly.
LogLevel configurations are configured in Configurations and environment's file.

1. 1.7.3Transport
   \*\* \*\* Below are the two transports,

   1.File transport 2. Console Transport

1. 1. 1.7.3.1File Transport
      By default logs are getting log to the below mentioned path,
      %USERPROFILE%\AppData\Roaming\<app name&gt;\log.log and file path and fileName can be customizable.
      By default it creates the log.log file in the above mentioned path, we can customize the fileName. In our application we have created a file with the filename 'bose-raphael' (logFileName:'bose-raphael' )in the above mentioned path.
      Developed the roll-over-by-size logs also, when particular log file size exceeds more than 1MB,it will create a new log file with this name 'bose-raphael1563165764375-archive'. appending date and achieve keyword to the old log files.
      Maintaining only 10 log files (logsFileCount:10 ) in the above mentioned path, if more than 10 files are getting create we are deleting the first created log file.
      Have option for disabling the log files , below is the syntax to disable the logs writing to a file log.transports.file.level = false;
1. 1. 1.7.3.2Console Transport
      Just prints a log message to application console (main process) or to DevTools console. We can disable the console logs also, following is the syntax to disable the console logs.

log.transports.console.level = false;

1.8Error & Exception handling 1. 1.8.1Exception handling
Exception handling has been handled in angular code by including global error handler file in app.module, whenever any unexcepted exception occurs in the front code (Angular Framework) global error handler file will automatically catch the exception and shows error message to the user.

Below is the method called in case of exception, in this method we are logging the error also using this.logError() method.

handleException(error) {

this.logError(error);

this.showErrorWithAutoClose(errorMessages.ExceptionOccured);

}

1. 1.8.2Error Handling
   These errors are the expected errors in the code ,these errors are handled through the error service If any exception occurs in the backend code(electron and controller folder),returning that exception to angular code and making a call to error service to display the error popup message. Below is the example use of errorservice.

import { ErrorService } from'@core/error/error.service';

this.errorService.showError(errorConstants.DeviceError);

1.9Unit Testing
"JEST" is the testing framework used in this application to write the unit test cases.

"jest.config" is the configuration file for jest related configurations, Below are the configurations

preset:'jest-preset-angular',

setupFilesAfterEnv: ['&lt;rootDir&gt;/setupJest.ts'],

transform: {

'^.+\.tsx?\$':'ts-jest'

},

testRegex:'(/**tests**/.\*|(\.|/)(test|spec))\.(jsx?|tsx?)\$',

testPathIgnorePatterns: ['/node_modules/'],

moduleFileExtensions: ['ts', 'tsx', 'js', 'jsx', 'json', 'node']

Mocks for some of the node modules like electron, electron-log ,node-hid, usb are located in **mocks** folder in root of the application. Jest framework will use these mocks in the test suite. Any additional functionality can be mocked using jest.fn() mock function. Refer jest documentation for more details.

To run all test suites use the below command.

Yarn test

For electron, test scripts should be created in electron/test folder.

For server code, test scripts should be created in server/test folder.

For angular use the cli to generate the test files.

Below are the some examples of unit test cases:

it('ipc main to be called', () =&gt; {

expect(ipcMain.on).toHaveBeenCalledTimes(1);

});

it('ipc main to be called with parameter', () =&gt; {

expect(jest.spyOn(ipcMain, 'on').mock.calls[0][0]).toBe('asynchronous-request');

});

1.15Notification

Use NotificationService from SharedModule and invoke the showNotification method on the service. The showNotification method accepts NotificationData as an argument.

NotificationsData object can be configured with the following properties

Property name Default value Description
message null The message to be displayed in the notification.
showButton true Display a button on the notification.
closeAction manuallyClose Enum of type NotificationCloseActionType with following values – autoClose (close notification after delay), manuallyClose (required to close manually)
timeout&lt;optional&gt; null Required if closeAction is autoClose, the timeout after which the notification should close.
returnMessage null
titleMessage Notification Alert The title to be displayed on the notification.
messageType success Enum of type NotificationType with following values – success, error, info, warning.
buttonText Close The text to be displayed on the button.
verticalPosition bottom Enum of type NotificationVposition with following values – top, bottom.
horizontalPosition right Enum of type NotificationHposition with following values – left, right, center, start, end.

1.20Project structure

Folder Structure details

Code related to electron api like – Creating Browser Window, Menu and sub-menu items must be implemented in electron folder.

Core business logic where nodejs layer communicates with 3

rd
party dependency like – 'node-hid', 'usb', etc. This must be implemented in server/controller folders.

Angular Components, Modules, Services, Directives, Pipes, Guards, Interceptors, etc. Will be implemented in src folder.

Custom Modules like - Angular-Material Module, Flex-Layout Module must be created a separate module which will come in shared/modules and exported to other modules which requires it.

Angular Folder structure is customized to obtain the scalability and maintainability of code, so we have divided in to Module based architecture i.e- Core Module, Shared Module and Feature Modules. (Note: Feature Module can be 'n' as per new feature added by BOSE Team)

Core Module: takes on the role of the root AppModule , but is not the module which gets bootstrapped by Angular at run-time. The CoreModule should contain singleton services (which is usually the case), universal components and other features where there's only once instance per application.

Auth: authentication folder simply handles the authentication-cycle of the user (from login to logout)
The footer, header, navbar, etc folders contains the global component-files, statically used across the entire application. These files will appear on every page in the application.
Guard: The guard's folder contains all of the guards I use to protect different routes in my applications.
Mock: Mocks are especially useful for testing, but you can also use them to retrieve fictional data until the back-end is set up. The mocks folder contains all the mock-files of our app.
Shared Module: The SharedModule is where any shared components, pipes/filters and services should go. The SharedModule can be imported in any other module when those items will be re-used. The shared module shouldn't have any dependency to the rest of the application and should therefore not rely on any other module. Note: The components folder contains all the "shared" components. This are components like loaders and buttons, which multiple components would benefit from. The directives, pipes and models folders contains the directives, pipes and models used across the application.
**Feature Module: ** This module will be solely related to business requirement. For Ex- We can think each tab or menu items in navbar as separate module. Using Lazy-loading of a module will optimize the performance of loading the module only when it is required.
All the global variable related to angular must be declared in environment.ts (For Dev Environment) and environment.prod.ts (For Production Environment)
Assets Folder must contain all the assets related to your project like icons, images, logo, etc.
Global Style must be declared in style.scss
Electron/Shared folder is created which will be used to develop all shared electron components like – dialog, windows, menu, etc.
e2e is used to implement end to end test case using protractor.
All angular unit test case will be written in file extension .spec.ts for component, module, service, etc.
Configuration Settings

Prettier Configuration

Also Enable Format on Save Setting to true

• Using IPC methods to communicate between Frontend and backend.

• Backend service are written in typescript itself.

• Business logic (Fetching list of devices from 'node-hid' dependency) written/implemented in backend only.

We have done POCs to evaluate different approaches to finalize the project structure. Details of the POCs are available in annexure section.

1.21Environment specific commands
Commands Description
yarn start Execute the app in the Windows as Desktop App (with features like : Running parallelly Electron and Angular Code, hot-reloading, etc). Command for development.
yarn ng:serve:web Execute the app in the browser
yarn build Build the app. Built files are in the /dist folder.
yarn build:prod Build the app with Angular aot. Built files are in the /dist folder
yarn electron:local Builds application and start electron
yarn electron:windows On a Windows OS, builds your application and creates an app consumable in windows 32/64 bit systems
yarn electron:mac On a MAC OS, builds your application and generates a .app file of your application that can be run on Mac
yarn lint:all Checks linting for JavaScript and TypeScript files.
1.22Coding standards and guidelines
Follow Standard Coding guidelines for Angular- https://angular.io/guide/styleguide
Create scalable folder structure for both Angular project and Node/Electron project ex- https://itnext.io/choosing-a-highly-scalable-folder-structure-in-angular-d987de65ec7
Make sure folder structures are loosely coupled so that it will be easy to add on new feature in future point of time
Make sure naming convention for project name, module/folder name, file name, class name, variable name, function name, const name has been followed. (Different casing : spinal-case, kebab-case, caterpillar-case, dash-case, hyphen-case , PascalCase, snake_case, SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE, kebab-case, TRAIN-CASE, Studly caps) –Should Know which casing to be used when.
Follow standard Design pattern(s) for common Loop holes/problems using Anti-pattern like: Singleton design pattern (by creating singleton service), Observer design pattern (Using observable-subscribe pattern), etc.
Define Global variable & const in config/environment folder/file.
Always use principles like DRY, DIE, KISS, YAGNI, SOLID, GRASP, SRP, SSOT, etc refer: Clean Code by Robert C M
Follow declarative or Imperative way of coding as per needed
Hardcoded string should be moved to constant file
Always write re-usable functions and make sure each unit of function /work should be delegated to its own unit testable
No data mutation and Memory Leak
Make sure code does not SMELL (Use Linting tools: Sonarts, etc)
Write Unit Testing for each functionality you have developed ex- Isolation testing, Integration/Functional testing (Both Shallow and Deep). Follow DAMP not DRY, also make sure specific threshold of Code coverage is done.
Typescript should be used

[ANNOTATION:

BY 'Tejas Shailesh Sabunkar' ON '2019-06-11T15:23:00'TS NOTE: 'Mentioned more specificly, thanks for comments']

[ANNOTATION:

BY 'Gayathri Rajamanickam' ON '2019-06-10T23:21:00'GR NOTE: 'what is efficient? and not efficient?'] efficiently in Angular for ex- Strong typing / Static typing, always specific the data-type for variables declared, function return type, function input parameters, etc.

JavaScript code should follow the recommendations specified at http://airbnb.io/javascript/

For Nodejs wrapper Please follow best practice for JavaScript casing:

Project Name : spinal-case or snake_case
Module/folder name : spinal-case or snake_case
File name : spinal-case or snake_case
Class name : PascalCase
Variable name : lowerCamelCase
function name : lowerCamelCase
const name : SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE
Electron Best practices:

To improve security for electron app use: The sandbox model can be activated, node integration can be turned off, preload scripts and webviews create local environments with different permissions
Separate Folders should be created for Main and Renderer Process
To protect our plain source code from end user who can temper it by extracting from asar file. So, use a couple of obfuscation and encryption techniques like –crypto, etc
General Electron Guidelines:
End files with a newline
Place requires in the following order
Built in Node Modules (such as path)
Built in Electron Modules (such as ipc, app)
Local Modules (using relative paths)
Place class properties in the following order:
Class methods and properties (methods starting with a @)
Instance methods and properties
Avoid platform-dependent code:
Use path.join() to concatenate filenames.
Use os.tmpdir() rather than /tmp when you need to reference the temporary directory
Using a plain return when returning explicitly at the end of a function
Not return null, return undefined, null or undefined
Naming in Electron API's:
When the module itself is a class like BrowserWindow, use PascalCase.
When the module is a set of APIs, like globalShortcut, use camelCase.
When the API is a property of object, and it is complex enough to be in a separate chapter like win.webContents, use mixedCase.
For other non-module APIs, use natural titles, like &lt;webview&gt; Tag or Process Object

6CODE QUALITY

1.24Linting Tools Rules

Linting is a process that analyses source code to flag programming errors, bugs, stylistic errors, and suspicious constructs. We are using linting process for static code analysis in USB application to maintain code quality.

Below are the tools used for the Javsascript and Typescript linting process.

Angular

Codelyzer - https://github.com/mgechev/codelyzer - Static code analyzer, specifically for designed for Angular
SonarTS - https://github.com/SonarSource/SonarTS - having 100+ rules that deals with cyclomatic complexity and cognitive complexity, etc,
TSLint - https://palantir.github.io/tslint/- extensible static analysis tool that checks TypeScript code for readability, maintainability, and functionality errors
Airbnb Typescript -https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint-config-airbnb-typescript
Electron - Since we are writing typescript for building over electron API, the same linting is applicable as showed above
NodeJS
Eslint - https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint
Airbnb EsLint - https://www.npmjs.com/package/eslint-config-airbnb
1.25Code Review Guidelines
Before providing the code for review, run "Yarn install" and "Yarn test"(for test cases) on the root directory of the repo. There should be no build failures and test case failures.
Before providing the code for review, run "package command or build command" on the root directory of the repo. Packaging should be successful.
There must be method and class level comments present for all the methods and classes.
Linting process should be completed
Code should be verified to follow coding guidelines followed for USB application
Proper comments should be present for all of the important business logics.
There should not be any commented-out code present.
Proper logs should be present for all important scenarios.
1.26Manual Review Process
Manual code review is the process of scanning and going through source code line-by-line in an attempt to identify potential vulnerabilities
Manual code review process happens before we merge 'feature' branch into develop branch
The reviewer team works individually to review the application as a whole
After the individual code reviews are completed, the team meets to share results
Each reviewer has the chance to review the others' findings, providing an opportunity to discuss why certain findings may appear in one team member's list but not in another's
This phase also helps to ensure that the findings being reported are relevant.
The final list of findings, along with descriptions and potential mitigations, is then presented to the developers using a standard report format
when we raise a GitHub request for merging the feature branch code with develop branch we can assign reviewer name in GitHub. Reviewer can put the review comments in comment section before merging the code with develop branch.
7Branching strategies
The following approach will define how we are going to setup git repo

Master : We consider origin/master to be the main branch where the source code of HEAD always reflects a production ready state.
Develop : Development branch again branch out from master and serve as development environment. Every feature branch will be pushed into develop branch after code review.
Feature : Feature branches are used to develop new features for the upcoming release. The essence of a feature branch is that it exists as long as the feature is in development but will eventually be merged back into develop.
Release: Release branches support preparation of a new production release and they allow for minor bug fixes and preparing meta-data for a release (version number, build dates, etc.).
Hotfix: Hotfix branches are very much like release branches in that they are also meant to prepare for a new production release, albeit unplanned. Hotfix branches also can be used for production bug fixes.
Apart from all these branches created from master repo we can have a scenario where we are going to create a repo for shared code. The shared code repo will contain all the reusable components which will be used in across the platform (I.e. Desktop, Web). While a new feature implementation, the reusable code will remain in Release branch till all the updation related to the that common feature is not released to consumer repos.

Naming convention:

Feature: feature/&lt;jira ticket number&gt;

Release: release/&lt;version&gt;

Hotfix: hotfix/&lt;version&gt;

8Build and Packaging

1.27Build installer for Windows and Mac

To distribute electron application across the platform we need to build the application. In order to build an electron application, we are going to use "electron-builder" tool. Electron builder gets the settings from electron-builder.json file put on the application root folder. An object has been created in Json file named "build". It has separate object values for Windows as well as Mac.

Windows: Electron builder builds the application and creates a .msi file installer for Windows platform.
Mac: Electron builder builds the application and creates a .dmg file installer for Mac platform.
1.28Packaging
Whenever adding new node module, first check for build compatibility for both windows and macOs. Please follow these steps below to validate compatibility.

Yarn install &gt;&gt; Skip if you have installed dependencies already.

Npm rebuild &gt;&gt;

Yarn electron:rebuild &gt;&gt;

Yarn electron:windows / Yarn electron:mac

9ANNEXURE

1.29Project Structure

Different ways of using Electron API's in Angular : ( POC : Taking input value from user in browser and writing the same into client's desktop in .txt format)

Directly importing Electron in Angular: Using ' ngx-electron' dependency, We can import ' NgxElectronModule' in providers arrays and can be injected to any of the component which requires native electron API's. Limitation : Only certain/limited API's of electron can only be used at client side, Cannot utilize all the API's provided by Electron at client side. POC : https://github.com/Tejas-Sabunkar-Mindtree/writeinput-to-file-ng-electron.git

Using Angular-Electron Kickstarter Project: Using angular-electron kickstarter project, So that we can configure as per required. It also provide feature like hot reloading. Also we can write our back-end code in Typescript itself, So that we can maintain uniformity in language for both front-end & back-end POC : https://github.com/Tejas-Sabunkar-Mindtree/ng7-electron-kickstarter.git

Deploying node offline: Creating node project and packing it to .tgz file and later import in Angular project. POC :

https://github.com/Tejas-Sabunkar-Mindtree/node-api-ng-consumer_import.git

https://github.com/Tejas-Sabunkar-Mindtree/node-api-producer_pack-publish.git

Deploying node online: Creating node project and publishing it to npm repository and later importing in Angular project. For this we require private repository in npm POC :

https://github.com/Tejas-Sabunkar-Mindtree/node-api-ng-consumer_import.git

npm i bundleproject

From the following approach we have finalized to take 2

nd
Approach because of following reason:


[ANNOTATION:

BY 'Tejas Shailesh Sabunkar' ON '2019-06-12T20:05:00'TS NOTE: 'When we directly try to us electron API in angular, We will get error : 'fs, os path not found', this error has been resolved by using this angular-electron kickstarter project']

[ANNOTATION:

BY 'Gayathri Rajamanickam' ON '2019-06-12T09:21:00'GR NOTE: 'not clear on this'] 'fs,os path not found' error while using electron API in the angular has been resolved (When importing any of the electron api in angular), hot-reloading available,

while using &lt;router-outlet&gt; then reloading electron app is resolved in this kickstart project.

Features Added to Existing Angular-Electron Kickstarter Project:

Angular Material is incorporated for Material Designing the Angular Component
Yarn is used for Dependency Management.
Separate Folder created for Electron, Nodejs (backend code) as server, configured accordingly.
Linting for Typescript updated with Codelyzer, Airbnb and Sonarts (Currently All files Pass Liniting)
Removed unwanted files and re-structured the Kickstarter project as per our need
Git link : https://github.com/Tejas-Sabunkar-Mindtree/ng7-electron-kickstarter.git
